abstract.p: Management of patients with functionally univentricular heart encompasses a wide array of developments over the years in every country. This article describes our working group experiences and 30-year story of single ventricle surgery in Turkey. Diagnosis, surgical treatment, and medical treatment of this complex group of patients necessitate courageous and continuous team effort with multi-institutional collaboration.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a working group participating in the surgical management of patients with functionally univentricular heart from the very beginning in Turkey, we would like to present our personal and group experiences as well as a discussion of our current strategies of Fontan management. We believe that this account of the evolution of our group’s approaches to single ventricle management is fairly representative of the general experience in our country.

Fontan’s operation was originally designed as an orthoterminal procedure for the patients with tricuspid atresia and was eventually applied to other types of univentricular heart and to patients with high-risk pathologies for biventricular repair. 1
–5 With better understanding of Fontan physiology and surgical modifications, Fontan’s operation has become the most common procedure performed for congenital heart disease after the age of two years. 6 Lateral tunnel and extracardiac Fontan modifications have led to significant improvements in the early and late outcomes with better flow dynamics and reduced energy losses, but there are still some concerns about the long-term complications such as atrial arrhythmias, atrial dilatation, ventricular failure, thromboembolism, and protein losing enteropathy. 7
–16 These long-term problems possibly originate from the absence of a subpulmonary pumping chamber, lack of pulsatile flow, and progressive elevation of systemic venous pressure.

sec.title: Evolution of Surgery for Functionally Univentricular Heart in Turkey
sec.p: Fontan experience in Turkey started in 1980 at Hacettepe University, Ankara. The first Fontan operation was performed by Dr Coşkun İkizler on a patient with tricuspid atresia. It was a Björk modification of Fontan’s operation, incorporating the small right ventricle in the Fontan pathway. That patient is still alive with two normal children. The article published in 1979 by Gale and associates from Mayo Clinic was one of the inspiring articles for us. 17 One week after reading this manuscript, the first atriopulmonary Fontan procedure in Turkey was performed by Dr Sarioglu on a patient with functionally single ventricle. 18

Our Fontan story encompasses two main eras: 1980 to 1998 and 1999 to current date. After initial experiences, we performed atriopulmonary connection-type Fontan operations until 1998. Since then, we have started to use the extracardiac Fontan modification.

Before the era of the extracardiac conduit type of Fontan procedure, we introduced a modification of Fontan’s procedure for instances of single ventricle with left atrioventricular valve atresia in which we utilized a right atrial flap for the neoseptation of the atriums. In this operation, the right atrium was opened using the incision as illustrated in Figure 1A to C. After complete resection of atrial septum and cut-back of the roof of the coronary sinus, the upper wall of the right atrium was brought down in such a way that pulmonary venous drainage was directed to the main ventricular chamber. The ceiling of the right atrium was connected to the pulmonary artery. The anterior wall of the right atrium was reconstructed using a piece of autologous pericardium. This technique, which we refer to as “right atrial flap neoseptation,” results in the creation of a large and unobstructed pulmonary venous pathway into the main ventricular chamber in patients with left atrioventricular valve atresia or common atrioventricular valve. Moreover, this method also maintains the integrity of the pulmonic venous atrium, which can make an important contribution to the Fontan physiology. We published a description of this Fontan modification 19 in 1994. We have used this modification in 12 patients, of which four had mitral atresia. Magnetic resonance imaging, 23 years after the operation, revealed the following findings: no right atrial dilatation, excellent function of the Fontan circulation, sinus rhythm, normal flow velocities, nonobstructive pulmonary venous pathway draining into the main ventricular chamber, and excellent ventricular function (Figure 2A and B).

Magnetic resonance views of the right atrial flap neoseptation technique 23 years after the operation.

sec.p: In 1998, just before we transitioned to the use of the extracardiac Fontan with autologous pericardial tube, the report from Hanley and associates was another inspiring and motivating article for us. 20 In the late 1990s, when the long-term complications of atriopulmonary connection type of Fontan procedure had become obvious, we adopted the extracardiac Fontan. Because of our preference for this procedure, the number of lateral tunnel modification in our series is limited.

For the extracardiac pathway, we are using a hand-made autologous pericardial tube of 18 to 20 mm diameter. If there is no available autologous pericardium, a bovine pericardial tube is used for the extracardiac tunnel (Figure 3A and B). Early results of our extracardiac Fontan procedure have been published 21 in 2005.

caption.p: Extracardiac Fontan with fresh autologous pericardial tube. A, Use of pericardial tube in levocardia and (B) use of pericardial tube in dextrocardia.

sec.p:
The search for better flow design is continuing. 22
–25 Whether the caval offset should be oriented to the right or to the left is debatable. We believe that the spatial configuration with “inferior vena cava to the left and superior vena cava toward the right pulmonary artery” provides better flow dynamics. Because of this reason, we prefer caval offset to the left.

Contemporary Fontan modifications have led to improvements in the early and late outcomes of Fontan surgery. The survival rate after extracardiac Fontan is expected to be better. 26,27 Other potential advantages of the autologous pericardial tube are easy availability, easy handling, low risk of thrombosis and embolism, better hemostasis, no cost, low risk of degeneration, and higher survival rates.

sec.title: Extracardiac Fontan or Lateral Tunnel. Which Is Better?
sec.p: As we all know, we do not have randomized studies to compare these two methods. This issue was discussed at the meeting of the American Association for Thoracic Surgery in Toronto in 2010. After reviewing the world literature, Backer and associates concluded that the extracardiac Fontan is superior to the other Fontan modifications on the basis of the following concepts: avoidance of myocardial ischemia, reducing the need for atriotomy incisions and intra-atrial suture lines, low operative mortality, improved hemodynamics, minimal flow disturbances and energy losses, low incidence of early and late arrhythmias, and applicability to a wide variety of complex cardiac anatomy including systemic and pulmonary venous return abnormalities. 28 Of course, the counter arguments stressing the advantages of the lateral atrial tunnel were presented as part of the same symposium.

We have performed atriopulmonary Fontan operations in 59 patients and extracardiac Fontan operations in 71 patients. In all, 28 (39.4%) patients had single ventricle, 18 (25.4%) had tricuspid atresia, and 25 (35.2%) had other types of complex functionally univentricular hearts (unbalanced atrioventricular canal defect, criss-cross heart, and transposition of great arteries with straddling atrioventricular valves). Two thirds of the patients were male and median age was five years (3-24 years). Early mortality was 20% for atriopulmonary Fontan operation and 5.6% for extracardiac Fontan operation. We attribute the improved mortality in the more recent era of the extracardiac Fontan modification to improvements in surgery, anesthesia, intensive care unit management, patient selection, and better flow dynamics. Before the extracardiac Fontan era, 12 patients underwent the right atrial flap neoseptation modification and lateral tunnel Fontan procedures were performed in 11 patients. Fontan-related surgeries were performed in 103 patients (Kawashima operations was performed in 19 patients, one and a half ventricle repair in 9, bidirectional cavopulmonary anastomosis in 66, Fontan revisions in 9; Table 1). Forty-six of the extracardiac Fontan patients were followed up for 99 ± 22 months (5-10 years) and late mortality occurred in two patients (4.3%; 1 sudden death and 1 intracardiac thrombus formation despite anticoagulation). One patient developed protein losing enteropathy (2.1%). Three patients had moderate or severe atrioventricular valve insufficiency (6.5%). Oxygen saturation was >94% in 39 (84.7%), ventricular ejection fraction was >50% in 44 (95.6%), sinus rhythm was maintained in 44 (95.6%), and functional capacity was class I to II according to New York Heart Association Classification in 43 patients (93.4%). It has become apparent that patients with atriopulmonary Fontan are more likely to need Fontan conversion due to right atrial dilatation, supraventricular arrhythmia, and thromboembolic complications. Our early results of Fontan revisions were published 29 in 2006. We performed Fontan conversion on nine patients: the original procedures were atriopulmonary Fontan in 6 and Kawashima operation in three patients. The indications for the conversion were atrial dilatation, atrial arrhythmia, and arterial desaturation (Figure 4A and B). Conversion techniques were lateral tunnel Fontan in six patients and extracardiac conduit in three patients, in combination with right atrial and pulmonary artery reconstruction. It was interesting to observe that in three patients who had conversion to an extracardiac Fontan circuit, sinus rhythm was restored without performing Maze procedure. Three patients with previous Kawashima operation developed pulmonary arteriovenous fistulae. Six months after the conversion, fistulae had regressed and arterial O2 saturation increased from 60% to 90% (Figure 5A and B).

sec.p: We acknowledge the pediatric cardiologists’ role for their important contribution in treating patients with failing Fontan physiology in the face of residual defects or obstructions. In one of our patients, multiple fenestrations between the right atrium and extracardiac tunnel were closed with two covered stents. Fenestrations in this patient occurred due to erosion of the bovine pericardial tube conduit (Figure 6A and B).

sec.title: Summary of Our Current Approach to the Patients With Functional Single Ventricle
sec.p: For patients with decreased pulmonary flow, we perform a central shunt and atrial septectomy (if atrial septal defect is restrictive) in the neonatal period. After four to six months, cavopulmonary anastomosis is done, and finally, at the age of two to three years, the extracardiac Fontan operation is performed. For patients with increased pulmonary flow, we perform pulmonary banding in the neonatal period. After four to six months, cavopulmonary anastomosis is done, and finally, at the age of two to three years, extracardiac Fontan operation is performed. Based on our group’s experience, we believe that the most important factors adversely influencing early and late outcomes of Fontan circulation are elevated pulmonary artery pressure (>15 mm Hg mean), small pulmonary artery size (McGoon ratio <1.8 and Nakata index <250 mm2/m2), ventricular dysfunction, and significant atrioventricular valve insufficiency. Although fenestration is routinely used in many series, we prefer to reserve fenestration for selected cases, in accordance with the new data supporting this idea. 30 –32

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Over the past three decades, the evolution of Fontan surgery has been followed up closely in Turkey. We have been inspired by many pioneers of single-ventricle surgery and many modifications of the Fontan procedure were adopted. In addition to the lateral tunnel and extracardiac Fontan modifications, our “right atrial flap neoseptation technique” might be a viable alternative modification that creates a contractile left atrium and unobstructed pulmonary venous pathway draining to the main ventricular chamber in certain patients with functionally univentricular heart. Use of an autologous pericardial tube is a worthy option for extracardiac conduit with low risk of thromboembolic and obstructive complications. Routine fenestration may not be necessary in extracardiac Fontan operations with appropriate selection of patients, contemporary surgical techniques, and currently available medications. Fontan conversion is expected to yield successful results for patients who had atriopulmonary connection and developed atrial dilatation and thrombus or atrial arrhythmia. We support the idea of early conversion to extracardiac or lateral Fontan operation in patients with the signs of Fontan failure after atriopulmonary connection. Contemporary Fontan modifications have led to improvements in early and late outcomes of Fontan surgery. The early and late survival rate after extracardiac Fontan is expected to be better in the coming decades.
